text:
Incentive fees for private equity funds are typically 20% of profits, but these fees are
not earned until after the fund has returned investors’ initial capital. It is possible that
incentive fees paid over time may exceed 20% of the profits realized when all portfolio
companies have been liquidated. This situation arises when returns on portfolio
companies are high early and decline later. A clawback provision requires the manager to
return any periodic incentive fees to investors that would result in investors receiving less
than 80% of the profits generated by portfolio investments as a whole.
